REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Honorable R. L. Cochran, Governor ' and Members of the 53rd Session of the Nebraska Unicameral Legislature, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor and Members: In compliance with the laws of the State of Nebraska, Chapter 84-303, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska, 1929, I take the pleasure of presenting- herewith my biennial report, covering the two years from July 1 1938 to June 30, 1940. This report contains numerous state - ments ' and supporting schedules, listed under Table of Contents, Page 10. The statement of the state's resources and liabilities, as required by Statutes 4847, is shown in Statement No. 1, showing resources total - ing $78 679 571.73. Compared with June 30, 1938 this is an increase of $4,195,654.38. Items which caused said increase are as follows: Increase: Cash on hand $ 993,908.83 Delinquent Taxes 305,159.26 Income Hospitals (From Counties) 10,776.93 Income Hospitals (From Individuals)... 6,385.79 Lands, Buildings and Equipment 2,916,119.97 Cash due from County Treasurers 90,219.23 Decrease Bonds of State Trust Funds 126,915.63 Net Increase ?4,195,604.38 All outstanding unpaid state warrants have been deducted from the total cash shown as of June 30, 1940. The State has no bonded indebtedness. The cash on hand, shown at Schedule 1-A. totaled $5,927,369.95, as compared with the cash balance June 30, 1938 of $4,933,461.12; an increase of 5993,908.83. This condition of the state's treasury as shown on June 30, IP4O, is reflected mostly in the condition of the General Fund, as of that date no General Fund paid warrants were being carried as cash by the Treasurer. RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURES Statement of the receipts and expenditures appears on Pages 28 to 30, and a comparative classified statement covering receipts and expenditures during the years 1922 to 1940 inclusive appears on Pages 55 and 56. These figures show a gradual increase the past two years over foregoing years, as to both Current Revenue Re - ceipts and Expenditures, indicating added activities in State Govern - ment The total receipts for the biennium ending June 30, 1910, were. $62,971,244.48 and total expenditures for the same period were 561, - -803,680.07. Of the total receipts $60,779,974.06 were Current Revenue receipts and -$2,191,270.42 was income from Trust Funds and other Miscellaneous receipts. The total expenditures are classified as follows: Legislative and Ordinary Expenses $37,894,899.79 Capital Outlay and Public Improvements 21,835,030.65 Temporary Trust Funds Disbursed 2,163,749.63 $61,893,680.07

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS BONDS—STATE TRUST FUNDS The investment in bonds as of June 30, 1940, was $13,785,366.35 as against $13,912,281.98 on June 30, 1938. No losses were charged off by direction of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds during the period covered by this Biennial Report. I wish, however, to again direct attention to losses charged off several years ago. The said Board authorized the State Treasurer to charge off the following Permanent Fund investments: Whitney Irrigation District Bonds ... $39,024.00 P'Cohner Real Estate M0rtgage.................... 4,800.00 •;¦.•-¦ $43,824.00 This loss has to date not been restored as provided by the Consti - tution in Article 7, Sec. 9, which reads in part as follows: "All funds belonging to the state for educational purposes, the interest and income whereof only are to be used, shall be deemed trust funds held by the state, and the state shall supply all losses thereof, that may in any manner accrue, so that the same shall remain forever inviolate and luidiminished; " Therefore, it is suggested that the Legislature make some provision for reimbursing the Permanent School Funds for this loss. : ; : .... WARRANTS As the total receipts arid expenditures increase year after year, so also are the number of warrants issued. The number of warrants written and the total amounts for the two years July 1, 1938 to June 30, 1940, were as follows: Fiscal Year Ended Warrants Written Amount June 30, 1939.................208,020 $35,748,513.93 June 30, 1940................ .196,454 34,578,197.75 BASIS FOR STATE TAX LEVY ¦'¦•'.:; ¦;'¦'¦ •-.' --':.' .'.; >-:-. ¦¦ ¦¦¦ 1939 -.. ¦ ;'. ¦;'¦¦ ' . - Valuation of the State for taxation purposes..... .$2,047,519,591.00 Levy of 2.41 mills ...................... 4,934,522.00 Redemption Fund Levy of 2/10 of 1 mi 11...... 409,503.92 : ¦'•'•• ;..;; .;-:' .-•:¦'¦" 1940' •¦-•... ' 192,227.18 REDEMPTION FUND LEVY "¦' Under Section 77-1007, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska 1929, the State Board of Equalization is authorized to make a levy of two tenths of one mill, or such part thereof as may be necessary in establishing and maintaining a Redemption, Fund. The Redemption Fund Tax col - lected is included with the total amount of General Fund Taxes as shown by each county under Statement No. 5 of this report.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS INSANE TAX LEVY Section 83-756, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska, 1929, provides that the Superintendent of the State Hospitals shall certify to the Auditor of State quarterly, the amount due to such hospital from the several counties having patients chargable thereto. Statement No. 5-B of this report reflects status of the Insane Tax Fund as of June 30, 1940. The total amount of tax delinquent, $373,612.37. REGISTRATION OF BONDS During the biennium from July 1, 1938 to June 30, 1940, the Auditor's Office examined and registered bonds of the various political subdivisions of the state in the amount of $13,181,701.80 as shown in Statement No. 8. Of this amount, $8,252,687.18 were refunding bonds, §4,307,626.25 were original bonds and $621,388.37 were funding- bonds issued under L. B. 431 passed by the 1939 Legislature and which ex - pired December 31, 1940. Through refunding and funding considerable savings were afforded the taxpayer. Previous to this time it was necessary to write to the County Clerks in order to determine the outstanding bonded debt of the po - litical subdivision. There is now set up in the Auditor's office a record of the bonded debt of each of the political subdivisions and a day-to - day bookkeeping- record is kept so that at anytime the outstanding - debt of any subdivision can be obtained. Statement No. 9 shows the outstanding debt on June 30, 1940 totaled $69,019,857.78 exclusive of Public Power debt. This is a reduction of $1,869,692.95 over the two year period. Considering the increased building and expansion pro - gram promoted in great part by P. W. A. and W. P. A. grants, this is a very commendable reduction. Since the instigation and expansion of the Public Power and Irri - gation projects there has accrued $41,428,609.57 bonded debt, over $1,000,000.00 of which is made up of defaulted interest. This is set out in detail in Statement 88. This amount has not been added to the previously mentioned total debt since no court ruling has clarified the statute determining- whether or not such organizations are political subdivisions. We believe it should be considered as part of the total debt. This addition would bring the total state bonded debt to $110, - -448,467.35. I would suggest that the Legislature take steps to clarify and make more specific the procedure relative to the issuance of bonds of such Public Power and Irrigation Districts so that they may be on a basis similar to other political subdivisions of the state. This office has assisted several counties in bringing: up to date and modernizing- their bond records. Splendid cooperation is now being - had between the County Clerks and the Bond Examiner in keeping - state and county records in shape. Some counties still need improved records. With continued effort and cooperation we hope to accomplish these changes for the benefit of the public, and with better records we hope

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS that we/can be of more service in the future to those wishing informa - tion relative to the financial status of the political subdivisions in the state. .',.."": COUNTY BUDGET The County Budget as passed by our Legislature of 1937 and amended in 1939, applies to all counties and provides for the setting up of an annual budget for each office, department or activity. The budget shall show all proposed expenditures from funds ap - propriated for the administration, operation and maintenance of all offices and the anticipated income from all sources including taxes to be levied, fees, licenses and all other means of financing the proposed expenditures for the current year. Assistance by this office has been given counties in the prepara - tion of forms and preparing the budget. An appropriation for budget direction would be very beneficial to all counties. This would enable the Auditor of Public Accounts to supervise the making of the budget and to examine the operation of same during the entire year. UNIFORM ACCOUNTING ' Uniform Accounting procedure has been established in several of the county offices. A complete system has been approved and in - stalled in the; offices of the Clerk of District Court with very satisfac - tory results. "The offices of County Judge and County Sheriff have also been supplied with uniform methods of accounting. County Clerks have been given assistance in the installation of uniform Warrant Register and Budget Ledger which helps to facilitate the work when making the annual budget. ; The basic objective in the establishment of uniform accounting in all county offices, is mainly to reduce cost of government, using a standard stock form which can be procured from any of the printing companies and avoid the expense of individual records for each county, and to be helpful to county officials to lighten the burden of cumber - some superfluous records; ¦'.- :¦• EXAMINATION OF COUNTY RECORDS L. B. N0.]310 passed by the 52nd Legislature of Nebraska provides that a detailed examination be made of all books and accounts of the officers of the various counties in the state under the direction and supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts. During the past two years complete and comprehensive audits have been made in 91 of the 93 counties together with several special examinations made of officers upon request of the Attorney General, Grand Jury or County Boards. The reports on regular audits cover 1036 county officials and consist of 8589 typewritten pages.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS These examinations have been accomplished with eight examiners as provided by law. We recommend that all county offices be.audited annually and that needed appropriation be added to supply a staff suf - ficiently ample to complete a yearly examination of all county offices. SEMI-ANNUAL AUDIT OF STATE TREASURER The State Legislature at its 1939 session appropriated $1,000.00 for the semi-annual audits of the State Treasurer, and directed that said audits be made by the State Auditor rather than by a private auditing firm. Said audit 3 have been made as directed and report thereof sub - mitted to the Governor of the State. AUDITING OF STATE OFFICES During the past biennium, this office has conducted audits annually of the Clerk of the Supreme Court; Board of Educational Lands and Funds; Nebraska Liquor Control Commission; Game, Forestation and Parks; American Legion State Fund Relief; Metropolitan Utilities Dis - trict, Omaha; Nebraska State Racing Commission and the State Board of Agriculture (known as the State Fair Board). We have also made audits of the Department of Health; Department of Banking; Depart - ment of Insurance; Aeronautics Commission; the four State Normal Schools; the State Industrial School, Kearney; Attorney General's Of - fice; Adjutant General; State Historical Society; Division of Athletics; Barber Board; Fire Marshal and State Library. This makes a total of 34 State Departments and State Institution audits conducted by the State Accountant and his assistant during 1939 and 1940. A check of all State Institutions, State Departments, State Offices, etc., reveal that there are 58 of these offices which should be audited annually by the State Auditor. Most of the penal institutions and the larger State Departments, such as the Department of Agriculture and the Highway Department, all of which handle cash accounts, have not been audited for some years. Due to a lack of personnel and appropriation it is impossible to make these audits. FINIS All ftiis has been accomplished in spite of the fact that our ap - propriation was decidedly decreased in comparison with the previous appropriation for the State Auditor of Public Accounts. . We would welcome an inspection of our new records with reference to bond registrations and cancellations; of our audits and examinations of State and County officials as to thoroughness and completeness. Our report and records show, without a question of doubt, that all state institutions, state offices and county officials should be audited and examined annually, not only as to receipts and disbursements but also to show in detail all costs of these departments. Further, 'the auditing and accounting law should be enlarged to cover all political subdivisions below the county including the Justice of the Peace.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS We believe that these suggestions for new duties would meet with the approval of the people of Nebraska interested in good government. Often times good laws are passed without proper thought of adminis - tration of the lav/. It is not fair to the Auditor of Public Accounts to be asked by the people of Nebraska to act in accordance with the law and he be unable to do so due to lack of personnel and finances. For example, we have eight examiners whose duties it is to examine and audit all county officials in Nebraska's 93 counties in accordance with L. B. No. 310. This is an impossibility. With the experience gained during; the past two years and with the help of the next Legislature we will be better able to administer our duties during our next term in the office of the State Auditor of Public Accounts. ; : ..;. . Respectfully submitted, RAY C. JOHNSON, December 1, 1940. i State Auditor of Public Accounts TABLE OF CONTENTS ¦.•• .'¦.:./ ; . ',_':¦: ; ¦ '•,-¦•. v ; ... REPORT OP AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Governor's Office July 29, 1940. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment met at the Governor's office at 11:30 A. M., Monday, July 29, 1940 with all mem - bers present, as follows: Governor R. L. Cochran, Secretary of State Harry R. Swanson, State Treasurer John Havekost, State Auditor Ray C. Johnson and State Tax Commissioner Win. H. Smith. . The following basis for the 1940 levy was submitted by Tax Com - missioner Smith, who moved its adoption, which was seconded by Secre - tary of State Swanson and carried, all members voting aye. BASIS FOR 1940 STATE TAX LEVY The report of the State Auditor shows appropriations from the state general fund for the biennial period of 1939-41 to be. ; .$10,856,392.30 (The emergency appropriations for the same fund met from the 1939 levy totaled $192,224.91.) One-half of the biennial appropriations to be met from the 1940 general fund levy are........... .... . 5,428,196.15 Less available for general fund: Intangible Tax $114,623.35 Miscellaneous Collections . .806,424.55 921,047.90 Net appropriations to be met....... 4,507,148.25 Which amount is increased 5% in accordance with Sec. 77-1007, C. S. of Neb., 1929....................-.... 225,357.41 Total to be raised from 1940 General Fund Levy..... 4,732,505.66 The valuation of the state in 1940 for taxation pur - poses has been found to be.......................... .1,922,271,788.00 Applied to which a levy of 2.47 mills will raise...... 4,748,011.32 A redemption fund levy, as authorized by Sec. 77-1007, C. S. of Neb., 1929, of one-tenth of one mill will raise.... 192,227.18 Therefore the foregoing" levies for 1940 are hereby approved by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment this 29th day of July, 1940. GENERAL FUND RECEIPTS The Miscellaneous Collections for the General Fund as Set Forth by the State Auditor, are as follows: ...,-, GENERAL FUND RECEIPTS—MISCELLANEOUS : July 1, 1939 to June 30, 1940.
